fields.description:
h2. Actual Case on Attribute Name
The attribute name is rendered in black when there is newline within the element.
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet exclude-result-prefixes="xs"
version="3.0">
</xsl:stylesheet>
{code}

h2. Work Around
Delete the newline within the element.
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet exclude-result-prefixes="xs" version="3.0">
</xsl:stylesheet>
{code}

h2. Actual Case on Comment, CData and Processing Instruction
When there is newline within comment, CData and Processing Instruction, all the text will be rendered in black
{code:xml}
<root>
<![[CDATA this is
 cdata]]>
<!--
comment --><?pi
instruction ?>
</root>
{code}

h2. Work Around
The colour rendered correctly when there is no newline within.
{code:xml}
<root>
<![[CDATA this is cdata]]>
<!--comment -->
<?pi instruction ?>
</root>
{code}
fields.summary: Wrong colour rendered in xml code block when there is newline within a element.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39218].
  {panel}

While doing a basic search from the Issue Navigator, trying to select one of several projects with long project names starting with the same set of words or characters that extend beyond the 250px width of the project drop down menu, can be quite confusing to users. As the project names get truncated by the limited width and are hard to differentiate.
!ProjectMenu.PNG|width=30%!

It would be great to possibly extend the width of the project drop down menu to atleast 400 - 500px to allow for more visiblity.

*Workarounds*:
* Note that you should be able to see the project name in full, by hovering your mouse over each project name from the drop-down list.
* The project name can be shortened so that it correctly appears.
* It is possible to customise the JIRA UI by CSS to extend the width of the drop down menu. If you need assistance with that you could try posting on https://answers.atlassian.com, as this kind of customisations are beyond Atlassian Support Scope
* In the Project Field, the user could specify the project's unique project key to avoid confusion with the long project names.
fields.summary: Project drop down menu in Issue Navigator should make full Project Name visible

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39215].
  {panel}

h4. Situation
Issue statuses in Basic Search in the Issue Navigator can only be found by the translation of the language pack used by the current user. The same status in the Advanced search (or JQL), can only be found by the original value.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Set the Default language of JIRA to English
# Set the user language of JIRA to Dutch
# Create a status "Deleted"
# Through the Translate statuses option, add a translation to Dutch "Verwijderd"
# Generate issues in status "Verwijderd"

h4. Expected result
When searching for issues through the Advanced Search in the issue navigator (or other searches using JQL) in status "Verwijderd", the previously generated issues will be found

h4. Actual result
No issues can be found in status "Verwijderd". However issues can be found in status "Deleted
fields.summary: JQL can not use translated values for system fields

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39195].
  {panel}

A change log / version gadget showing an overview over the already released versions of projects would be quite handy. Visually I'm imagining basically something like the roadmap gadget but for already released versions.

You can already somehow achieve something like this with the two-dimensional filter statistics (see: attached screenshot), but that has two main drawbacks:
a) clicking on the versionnumber I'd like to be presented the release notes report of the project instead of the issue list for that version as it does atm (or some other means to access the release notes directly from within that gadget view)
b) visually it's not quite appealing (the style of the roadmap gadget would be much more preferable for a change log / version gadget).

Was also already suggested/discussed here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/37129/released-versions-change-log-gadget
fields.summary: Change log gadget

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce:* 
* Go to an issue.
* Open the Permission Helper Window
* Select a user with some permission allowing the user to not preform the selected function.

*Current Behavior:* The window is too big to display within the window at 100% zoom level and cannot selected the 'Submit' or 'Close' option.

*Expected Behavior:* The window is scaled to be observed fully and should posses a scrolling slider to navigate through the whole window.

*Workaround:* Zoom out to a smaller browser level using the options within the browser menu or the following hotkeys:

* For a mac: Command-Option-Minus (–)
* For a PC: CTRL-Minius (–)
fields.summary: Permission Helper Window Not Completely Visible at 100% Zoom Level
Hide/Show fields without reloading the page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39182].
  {panel}

We are using the "auto merge" features offered in Stash, specifically in the fashion of having an X percentage of reviewers approve and then auto merge.

The issue with that is, let's say i leave a comment that is not necessarily code related but more architecturally, which leaves me not to decline the merge request, but i also don't really want the request to be auto merged before the team or the developer can explain to me the what when and where.
 
In order to prevent the auto merge it would be awesome if i can "attach" the pull request to a task and if that task is in a certain (designated) column on the Agile board, the merge request will NOT be auto merged, no matter how many reviewers have approved the request.

The reason this would work better in the process, is because when i decline the request, others can't (easily) complete their review since the pull request is no longer clearly visible  for other users.
fields.summary: Link a Stash repo with a status on the Agile board
Hide assignee in personal Tasks list
Multiple Repositories Path to one JIRA Project.

fields.description:
Nick Mitchell here at CD-adapco opened a ticket to ask why his e-mailed comments weren't getting added to issues in JIRA.
Here are the log entries I found:

{noformat}
2014-07-18 06:52:28,976 WARN [jira@cd-adapco.com] QuartzWorker-0 ServiceRunner    Add Comment New This user is not in jira so can not add a comment: Nick Mitchell <nick.mitchell@cd-adapco.com>
2014-07-18 06:52:28,976 ERROR [jira@cd-adapco.com] QuartzWorker-0 ServiceRunner    Add Comment New Add Comment New[10271]: The mail 'FROM' does not match a valid user
 This user is not in JIRA so can not add a comment: Nick Mitchell <nick.mitchell@cd-adapco.com>
{noformat}

Look simple, right?  It was.

I found that when we'd created his JIRA account, we'd put a single space at the end of his e-mail address.  That was enough to stop the "Add Comment" mail handler from matching the FROM addresses with the e-mail in Nick's account.

Here is what we had entered for his e-mail address:
{noformat}
"nick.mitchell@cd-adapco.com "  <- not a typo, there was really a space
{noformat}

Outbound mail to users from JIRA works fine for Nick.

My guess is that someone didn't think to or choose not to strip trailing whitespace from the e-mail address during user creation and also when matching in the mail handler.

We have our accounts in the internal JIRA user directory, by the way.
fields.summary: Whitespace at the end of a users e-mail address breaks incoming mail for that user.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39175].
  {panel}

*Steps to replicate:*

# Create a project with a workflow that does not set the resolution at any point
# Change the edit screen so that it has the 'resolution' field on it
# Create an issue
# Edit the issue to set a resolution

*Result:*

Issue does not have a resolved date

*Expected result:*

The issue has a resolved date and resolutiondate in the database has been updated.

*Workaround*

The resolution field should be altered either through a post-function, or by a screen specifically used to resolve issues. You should *not* have the resolved field on the edit issue screen.
fields.summary: Changing a resolution by editing an issue does not set a resolved date

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Setting root level DEBUG can expose login information (username/pw) when JIRA is connected to Crowd for user management, as it outputs the REST POST contents that are transmitted through the HttpClient.

h3. Environment

Crowd integrated with JIRA for user management.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Integrate JIRA with Crowd for user management
# Within JIRA's administration panel, set DEBUG logging on the 'Default' level
# Log into JIRA as any Crowd user (for example: testuser / testpw)
# Check JIRA's application logs (atlassian-jira.log) or tomcat server logs (catalina.out)
(i) The above log files contains both the testuser and testpw in plain text.

h3. Expected Results

The password details are obfuscated in the logging.

h3. Actual Results

Note that it shows the password inputted by the user, which may or may not be the real pw, but in most cases users will have inputted the real password.

h3. Workaround
Modify the log4j.properties file and adding:
{code}
log4j.logger.httpclient.wire=WARN
{code}
* This will not prevent this exposure, but simply adds another layer before the exposure occurs.

h3. Notes

This is not specific to just JIRA/Crowd integration. It affects all of Atlassian's applications that integrate with Crowd.

h3. Why this is a problem
* It is common for Crowd to be integrated with LDAP or Google Applications
* Local Atlassian application administrator only has access to JIRA and the server hosting JIRA
** This administrator may not have access to any other system, such as LDAP, database, etc.
* If DEBUG logging on the 'Default' level is set and a high level executive logs into JIRA, their password for LDAP could be captured
* The local Atlassian admin can now gain access to the company's systems beyond their privileges.
fields.summary: Specify logging level to Prevent Root DEBUG from Exposing Login
Add jira-config.properties file to the Modified Files

Sam

h3. Current behaviour

If you integrate JIRA with Perforce, you will only have the option to map custom fields, not the system fields. There are only a few system fields mapped by default with Perforce, like "Issue Type" and "Priority", but not all the fields (like "Components", "Labels", etc.)

h3. Expected behaviour

Allow the user to map system fields to Perforce just as the custom fields.
fields.summary: Perforce doesn't allow JIRA to map system fields

fields.description: I don't see a way for an optional field to always be shown on a screen.  You have to set a default value for it to show up using some fictional value like "unspecified".  If the field is multi-valued, that means a user must delete the "unspecified" value when adding a real value.  Why can't the field be configured to always be displayed on a screen without requiring a value?
fields.summary: Optional field with no value does not display

fields.description:
There's been a few cases in support where it was reported that LDAP directory configuration settings suddenly disappeared from the database after a JIRA restart, making LDAP authentication impossible. In some cases there was degraded performance or a JIRA crash that occurred just before the incident.

There's been a KB that tells customers how to recover from this incident: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/JIRA+drops+LDAP+configuration+-+java.naming.provider.url+property+does+not+contain+a+URL. 

Because of the rarity of this problem, we've not been able to determine a easy way to reproduce the behaviour or how exactly the incident occurs. However, I'm raising this ticket because we need to have this issue tracked and looked into more properly somewhere. Hopefully there's something that can be implemented on the JIRA side to prevent this.
fields.summary: LDAP Configuration settings corruption

fields.description:
When a version is created using the "on the fly" creation feature, which was introduced with JIRA 6.3, the "VersionCreateEvent" is not firing.

In contrast the "VersionCreateEvent" occures when the version is created in the conventional way on the version administration screen.
fields.summary: "VersionCreateEvent" not firing when the "on the fly" creation feature is used

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39148].
  {panel}
h3. Problem Definition

I often create filters for users, especially those that are more complex or, because of my BA role, I create the initial filters and board setup for the product owners; however, the product owners (or those that are requesting my help), actually should own or manage the filters. 

Today, I create a filter, share it. Then that user is required to create their own and then change the filter for a board or gadget that the filter is often associated with. I have to remember to go back and delete these filters as I have no need to have them in my list. 

* As an administrator, we have hundreds if not thousands of filters that no one uses, but I have no way of knowing which ones they are to get them cleaned up. 
* As an administrator, I often get requests to go change ownership. 
* And, as an administrator and analyst, I often have to go in and change ownership to me, change their filter, and then change ownership back. 


h3. Suggested Solution
As an analyst, 
* I want to be able to change ownership or share ownership of a filter I created with/to another user so that they are able to manage the filter contents. 
* I want the ability to change the ownership of my own filters to someone else, or even better, actually share the ownership or management of a filter. 

h3. Note on Fix
The current ticket is superseded by JRASERVER-17783.
fields.summary: Change owner and share ownership of filters

Make the advanced JQL search box collapsible for longer JQL queries

fields.description:
The default login page (http://jira-address.com/login.jsp) is shown or linked to when it should redirect  the user to the SSO login page defined in the {{seraph-config.xml}} file.

h4. Steps to Reproduce:
# Configure the {{seraph-config.xml}} file as below:
{noformat:borderStyle=dashed| borderColor=#6A8EB3 |bgColor=#F8F8F8}
            <!--
              The login URL to redirect to when the user tries to access a protected resource (rather than clicking on
              an explicit login link). Most of the time, this will be the same value as 'link.login.url'.
                - if the URL is absolute (contains '://'), then redirect that URL (for SSO applications)
                - else the context path will be prepended to this URL

                If '${originalurl}' is present in the URL, it will be replaced with the URL that the user requested.
                This gives SSO login pages the chance to redirect to the original page
            -->
            <param-name>login.url</param-name>
            <!--><param-value>/login.jsp?permissionViolation=true&os_destination=${originalurl}</param-value>-->
            <param-value>http://my-custom-sso.com/login.jspa?redirectTo=${originalurl}</param-value>
        </init-param>
        <init-param>
            <!--
              the URL to redirect to when the user explicitly clicks on a login link (rather than being redirected after
              trying to access a protected resource). Most of the time, this will be the same value as 'login.url'.
                - same properties as login.url above
            -->
            <param-name>link.login.url</param-name>
            <!--><param-value>/login.jsp?os_destination=${originalurl}</param-value>-->
            <!--<param-value>/secure/Dashboard.jspa?os_destination=${originalurl}</param-value>-->
            <param-value>http://my-custom-sso.com/login.jspa?redirectTo=${originalurl}</param-value>
        </init-param>
        <init-param>
{noformat}
# Start JIRA;
# This behavior can be seen with the following, but is likely to be shown in different use cases as well:
#* Using a mobile device.
#* When JIRA's sessions expire, clicking on the "Log back in" link.
#* If you have two tabs open and click the "Log out" link in both, the second tab takes you to an "Already logged out" page with a bad "Log in again" link.
#* Using the Issue Navigator with JQL while logged out.
#* Opening an attachment from Jira Service Desk while logged out.
#* Opening an issue while on the <BaseURL>/projects/<ProjectKey>/issues page.

h4. Expected Behavior
Any requests to the {{http://jira-address.com/login.jsp}} URL should be directed to the SSO URL defined in the seraph configuration.

h4. Actual Behavior
Following the steps above, the http://jira-address.com/login.jsp page is shown. The http://jira-address.com/login.jsp page can also be accessed directly from the browser (without having to be redirected there)

h4. Workarounds

Redirect requests for the login page using a proxy rewrite rule. Here is an example for Apache ModRewrite:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %
{QUERY_STRING}
(?:^|&)os_destination=(.+?)(?:$|&)
RewriteRule ^/login.jsp$ YOUR_SSO_LOGIN_URL [NE,L,R=301]
{code}

In conjunction with this, disable the Login Gadget so it does not appear in Dashboards. The System Dashboards is visible without login so it is necessary to remove the gadget.
# Edit the file {{<JIRA_HOME_DIR>/jira-config.properties}} (create an empty file with this name if it does not exist)
# Add this line to the file: {code:borderStyle=solid}
jira.disable.login.gadget=true
{code}
# Save the file and restart JIRA
fields.summary: JIRA Seraph Config Settings are not Respected

Karine MARTINS

fields.description:
Hamlet returns 403 for some reason, this happens only on Safari 7 (didn't check previous Safari versions). It seems likely that this bug affects JIRA prior to version 6.2.7 as well.

*Update on Nov/2014:* It also affects Firefox (see https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-39131?focusedCommentId=669801&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-669801 for more details)

This behaviour is reproducible when the browser has not visited any *.atlassian.com site prior to the installation.
fields.summary: Cannot generate license during JIRA setup on Safari and Firefox

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39129].
  {panel}

Migrating from JIRA 6.1.6 to current JIRA 6.2.7, we detect a bug in the translation in 6.2.7. In the Issue screen, the status action button Reopen and start review located in the header is not translated into Spanish (es_ES). In JIRA 6.1.6 this action button label was translated and displayed Ok, but in 6.2.7 is not translated, showing the default english translation. Also the tooltip of the action button doesn't appears at all, as opposed of rest of action buttons that display tooltips translated.

!Screenshot1.png!

The translation is already available in JIRA 6.2.7

!Screenshot2.png!
fields.summary: Issue status action Reopen and start review not translated
jira-core 6.3 com.atlassian.jira.project.ProjectHistoryLinkFactory breaks API

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39127].
  {panel}

'Email From' (the pretty display name, not the actual address which is referred to as just 'From' in the global mailservers ui or 'Email' in the project ui) supports:
${fullname}, ${email} and ${email.hostname}

Sometimes it would be great to just have first_name (pull from database or use fullname till first space...) aka givenName

Additionally you even might want to use user_name (database) as it may be different than email / email_address (database).

fullname auto maps out: first_name, lower_first_name,last_name,lower_last_name,display_name,lower_display_name

and there's other key/values you can set on the user that would be great to expose, or in the future JRA-6354

such that you wouldn't have to put (blah/department) as part of the fullname to expose some info

"fullname (jira)" <jira@domain.com>
fields.summary: Support more variables in 'Email From' display such as first_name

fields.description:
From the page [http://jdbc.postgresql.org/download.html]:
bq.  If you are using the 1.6 then you should use the JDBC4 version. If you are using 1.7 or 1.8 then you should use the JDBC41 version.

Hence JIRA 6.x Java 7 is supported, but we still ship with {{PostgreSQL 9.0 JDBC4 (build 801)}}

h3. Workaround

Download the JDBC41 driver from http://jdbc.postgresql.org/download.html and replace the existing postgreSQL driver in {{$JIRA_INSTALL/lib}} with it.
fields.summary: JIRA is shipped with Postgres JDBC4 instead of JDBC41

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce
- Create Dashboard with single column layout
- Add Gadget 'Created vs. Resolved'
- Similar behavior when viewed in 'Wallboard mode'

h3. Expected results
- Full view of Gadget, or at least the ability to zoom out for full overview

h3. Actual results
- Bottom portion of Gadget is hidden from view and zooming in/out makes no difference

!fullscreen_gadget.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround
- Use a different Dashboard Layout
fields.summary: Unable to zoom on JIRA Gadgets

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39123].
  {panel}

Hi,

In your markup documentation:

https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/WikiRendererHelpAction.jspa?section=all

It is difficult for a new user to find the markup for "strikethrough", because it is erroneously called "deleted" in the documentation.

The correct term for this is "strikethrough", not "deleted".  See the wikipedia page: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strikethrough

If the documentation is updated accordingly, the result will be a better user experience.
fields.summary: Incorrect name used for strikethrough markup in documentation

fields.description:
We are facing problems regarding to create issues with due date 19/Oct/2014. It appears to be not recognized by JIRA or have a malformed format. However, entrying dates like: 18/Oct/2014 or 20/Oct/2014, JIRA accept them with no problem.

h3. Steps to reproduce

Have JIRA using the BRST timezone and try to set any date field to the third Sunday of October.

h3. Expected outcome:

You should be able to set the date.

h3. What really happens:

You receive the following error:

{code}
You did not enter a valid date. Please enter the date in the format "d/MMM/yy", eg. "15/Jul/14"
{code}

h2. Workaround:

Set a different timezone following the steps on [setting the timezone for the JAVA environment|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Setting+the+timezone+for+the+JAVA+environment].
fields.summary: Cannot enter some specific dates; All third Sundays of the October months of every year are rejected by JIRA. (Example: 19/Oct/14)
Allow JIRA Administrators to disable notifications per user

fields.description:
Hello everyone,

we are using Jira 6.0.8 with the jira-mail-plugin version 6.0.7. We have a lot of projects and mail handlers to create issues from incoming mails. We have problems with the generated description.
If you try to create an issue from mail with HTML body (via mailhandler), the text formatting will be broken. The text is shown at the description field, but in on single line. Every new line from the mail body will be removed.
The bug only appears, if every line at the HTML body is seperated by DIV-Tags.

It would be great for us, if this can be fixed.
fields.summary: Mail Handler, new lines will be removed in description field

fields.description:
0. Make sure there are many projects to choose from.
  1.Create an issue.
  2.Select a project from the drop-down list.
  3.Click on the vertical scroll bar.

Result: The list of projects disappears.

Workaround: Use the keyboard.
fields.summary: The Project list disappears after clicking on the scroll bar

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39113].
  {panel}

We have lot of projects with lot of versions and administrering is tedious - I must click the "cog" icon in the versions's line, then select the "Release" link in dropdown menu.

It was simplifier (and easier to use) in old versions of Jira - there were direct links "Release, Archive, Delete" in each version line.

Returning of direct links or implementing of keyboard shortcuts should make the work easier.

Thank you
fields.summary: Version administration shortcurts or direct links to version actions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39112].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

On moving Issue to another project, JIRA doesn't check the permission for Assignable User. JIRA should not fill that Assignee field during moving an issue, if the former assignee doesn't have *Assignable User* in project B.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an issue in projectA
 # Give UserA *Assignable User* permission for projectA
 # Assign the created issue in projectA to UserA
 # Create projectB
 # Move Issue from projectA to projectB

h3. Expected Results


Assignee field should be left blank as they original assignee doesn't have permission in projectB.
h3. Actual Results

The original assignee is still assigned the issue in projectB although he doesn't have *Assignable User* permission in projectB
h3. Notes

The Reporter field is also affected by this bug in the same way as described for the assignee field.

Issues can be also moved to another project  through "bulk change".
fields.summary: JIRA is not checking the Assignable User permission when moving an issue between projects

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39111].
  {panel}

In [JIRA 6.2 Release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+6.2+Release+Notes], in the "Simple issue type configuration" session, the screenshot and text are not very clear for the customers. By looking the screenshot, seems that any Project Administrator will see the option to configure the Issue Type workflow, by simply clicking on it. However, when you go to that screen, only if you are a Administrator you will see an "Edit Workflow" button on the top of that screen and then will be able to configure the Workflow:

!systemadmin.png|thumbnail!

In the actual screenshot, this button is not present however the user is able to edit the workflow. Here is what I see when I am a Project Administrator but not a Administrator:

!projectadmin.png|thumbnail!

It would be great if we can change that information to avoid any misunderstanding.
fields.summary: JIRA 6.2 release notes

fields.description:
How to Reproduce: 

1) Create a date picker custom field;
2) Set it to UPDATED as first step of a transition's post-function;
3) Instead of picking the current date as default, it picks the date use

Therefore my custom field should get the value of the current date.
Instead, it gets the date of the last update.

Workaround is to move it down to after the history is updated, so the correct value is put into the custom field. However by doing this the update of that field is NOT listed in the history.
fields.summary: Setting custom field to "Updated" field doesn't get current time

fields.description:
h3. Actual Results:

The Activity Stream causes confusion as it will show two Fix Version fields updated.

h3. Steps to reproduce:

# Create a Custom Field called _Fix Version_;
# Put one value for the Custom Field Fix Version_ and another value for the system field _Fix Version/s_ on an issue;
# On the Activity Stream, the values are changed. Activity Stream gets confused about this two fields.

h3. Expected Results:

JIRA should either handle this in a way that does not cause confusion or deny the creation of a custom field with the same name as system fields.

h3. Workaround:

Use a different name for the custom field.
fields.summary: Activity Stream does not recognise the difference between a system and a custom field.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39108].
  {panel}

Scenario:
# On my Jira Cloud instance, I create a user.
# In Chrome, I log into the instance with these credentials
# I issue the following REST API call in Chrome:
{code}
https://(instance)/rest/api/2/user/assignable/search?project=(project)
{code}

Expected:
* A list of users

Actual:
* Error 401 Unauthorized

*Remark1:*
If I issue the same query after logging in as the site administrator, I get the list of users

*Remark2:*
If I pump up the rights of the user above, up to be part of all groups, the REST API still doesn't go through, although the permission helper says this user is administrator of the project.
fields.summary: REST API authentication error when asking for list of users for a project

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39107].
  {panel}

When we create a JQL with nested parentheses (like the one from the screenshots), it works fine if we just perform a search.
 !query.png|thumbnail! 

However, if we try to save this query as a filter, JIRA removes the nested parentheses. Please see screenshot for more details.
 !saved_filter.png|thumbnail! 

Thanks!
-Jose
fields.summary: JQL removes nested parentheses when saving filter
Create a custom tab in JIRA issue view

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39104].
  {panel}

Hi,

I'm part of a software company.  JIRA is our lifeblood for support issues for our customers.  We actually have built a lot of internal applications fed data from/to JIRA so that people within our company can get information about our customers.

In many cases, we have folks who need to perform actions on customer information (look at their groups, change their groups, add them to groups).    This is something only allowable by jira-administrators.  These employees do not need to have access to everything else a jira-administrator has.

Has there been any consideration for making global permissions more granular than just "system-administrator" and "administrator?"
fields.summary: Additional Permissions/Roles in JIRA
Ability to Disable Add Field via View Issue page by Administrator

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39101].
  {panel}

Environment: Windows 7 Professional, SP1

Browser: Firefox ESR 24.6.0 ESR (corporate approved version) or Chrome Version 35.0.1916.153 m

Java 7 V60 (also automagically installed by corporate)

We used to be able to click the three grey dots in the Agile board view and select Atttach Screenshot and there would be a box where we could paste a clipped image. Now the container doesn't appear and clicking either the PrtScn button or Ctrl + V buttons does nothing. (see attachment:  attachattempt.jpg).  Entering a filename and clicking Upload generates a 500 error. (see attacherror.jpg, below)

I didn't change the system permissions. Adding attachments is still enabled. What happened and how do I get the ability to attach screenshots back? (Yes, I know I can save them and attach the file, but that's not quite as convenient).

I tried opening an issue and using More-->Attach Screenshot and it appears to be working properly.

We first noticed this problem around mid-June, 2014
fields.summary: Attach Screenshot not working in JIRA OnDemand (but it did before!) from Agile board (but works from open ticket)
Login

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39099].
  {panel}

Based on this documentation:
- [Changing the Project Key Format|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Changing+the+Project+Key+Format]

There is a list of supported project key pattern in which I believe to make sure that there is no confusion between Project Key and Issue Key.

But, with the Project Key Pattern is possible to be customized there is still a possibility that the user still input an unsupported project key pattern. Therefore, it would be useful if there is a validator or warning when the user tries to set an unsupported project key pattern.
fields.summary: Validation or Warning when Trying to Use Unsupported Project Key Pattern.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39098].
  {panel}

Documentation: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Running+JIRA+over+SSL+or+HTTPS
bq. You can also redirect users from HTTP URLs to HTTPS URLs by choosing the 'HTTP & HTTPS' profile in the JIRA configuration tool. However, if you want to only redirect certain pages to HTTPS, you can do this manually. *To do this*, select the 'HTTPS only' profile in the JIRA configuration tool and save the configuration.

The context of *To do this* above is not so clear.

It seems that the last statement in this paragraph is incomplete. It is currently easy to read the last to sentences together and come up with the idea: "... if you want to only redirect certain pages to HTTPS, you can do this manually. To do this, select the 'HTTPS only' profile in the JIRA configuration tool and save the configuration."

However, that doesn't make much sense and will be incorrect because:
# simply selecting the 'HTTPS only' profile in the JIRA configuration tool isn't sufficient to achieve http to https redirection
# Also,  "selecting the 'HTTPS only' profile in the JIRA configuration tool" in the later statement, doesn't match the context of "you can do this manually" in the previous statement.

I'm not sure if I explained the problem with the paragraph clearly.
fields.summary: Confusing/incomplete paragraph in Running JIRA over SSL documentation

fields.description:
h4. Symptoms

JIRA keeps deleted LDAP users in the system as disabled users if they have created content. When the audit log is enabled, each time a synchronisation occurs, a new "delete" entry appears in the audit log for users that have been kept disabled this way. No actual change has been made on this user.

h4. Steps to Reproduce

# Link up JIRA to an LDAP directory
# Create a user in the LDAP directory that has access to JIRA
# Log in as that user, create some content
# Delete the user from the LDAP directory
# Synchronise the directory
# Synchronise it again and see the delete entry re-appears

h4. Workaround

# Add the user back in the LDAP directory
# Make sure the user has no groups that give them access to JIRA, so that it doesn't use up a license
fields.summary: JIRA Audit Log repeats delete entries for users which are deleted from and AD or LDAP directory, but remain as disabled users in JIRA
Creating an issue with zoomed JIRA web interface
Add Resolution, Affects/Fix Version(s) in JSON export file

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39091].
  {panel}

As a JIRA administrator or user, I wish that JIRA introduces a system of error codes so that finding help on error situations is straightforward and requires less guess work and search engine gimmicks.

h2.Advantages
# A JIRA Project or Confluence space could be setup with the error codes for public documentation
# Errors in the JIRA UI could be linked to these error code pages so that administrators and users find it easy to solve problems
# When the error codes are printed in logs, troubleshooting or supporting will also be much easier.
fields.summary: Introduce error codes for supportability

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-39087].
  {panel}

This issue is mentioned in the comments by @Halley on JRA-1898, a rather old feature request. But I believe it's somewhat different than that issue and really should be filed by itself as a Bug.

Jira’s comment notification system isn’t really reliable because we can’t depend on users getting comment notifications all of the time.

We have set up a notification scheme that sends an email notification to all issue watchers and the issue assignee whenever anyone makes or edits a comment on the issue. This works fine when someone adds the comment from within Jira itself.

We also allow users to email back a reply to these notification emails, and we're set up so their email replies are added to the issue as and additional comment. This too works.

What doesn't work is, if a user includes any kind of attachment, regular or inline, in the reply email, Jira will not send a notification email that there is a new comment. If the user deletes all attachments, images, etc. before sending it, however, and just sends text in the reply, Jira will send out a notification. Either way the comment is still being added to the issue. It's just a problem with the notifications not being sent out unless the comment contains only text.

The problem is Jira assumes that anything that isn’t text in the email is an attachment. That includes things that aren’t really attachments, like inline images and logos that appear in the message or in a sig. Also, since every notification that Jira sends out has icons and logos in it, simply replying to these sends back a message full of “attachments,” thus defeating the comment feature and filling up the issue with garbage “attachments” that really should not be part of the issue record.

I can ask users to delete everything except their text reply when replying to a comment via email, but this isn’t really practical since, of course, your average user won’t remember to do that. Also, sending out a notification every time an issue is updated doesn’t work for us. Users will get way to many notifications over the course of the issues’ life, most of which they will not understand. We really just want to notify them of all new comments.

I see two possible solutions (this is in order of my preference)

1. If Jira had a setting to block attachments via email that would solve this problem (I know JEMH can do something like this, but its price is very high to use for only this purpose).

2. If Jira could be set to ignore any email attachment with “Content-Disposition: inline”, I think this also would fix this problem. If its “Content-Disposition: attachment” it should add it to the issue, but ignore otherwise.

BTW all users here have a Jira account, and this does not seem to be related to their "my changes" selection under their profile settings. Notifications aren't going out to anyone in these cases, regardless if they sent the reply or not.
fields.summary: Notifications of new comments not being sent out if comment comes from a reply to an email notification
